{"uri": "8251036799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:51:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:51:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:49:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/07/30/democrats-had-feared-georgia-was-a-lost-cause-with-biden-running-harris-will-campaign-there-tuesday/", "title": "Democrats Had Feared Georgia Was a Lost Cause With Biden Running. Harris Will Campaign There Tuesday", "body": "ATLANTA -- Little more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Vice President Kamala Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats say they have new hope for the state. They're betting that a fresh burst of energy and a surge in fundraising has helped make Georgia -- the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 -- a toss-up again.\n\nHarris is planning to make a show of political force with a rally in Atlanta at 7 p.m. ET on Tuesday, the latest example of just how much the race against Republican Donald Trump has shifted since Biden abandoned his reelection bid. She will be appearing in the same city where Biden's dismal performance in a debate against Trump on June 27 sparked a Democratic revolt that ultimately ended his campaign.\n\nHarris is hoping a large rally, featuring a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal with young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nRelated Story: Liberal 'White Dudes' Rally for Harris: 'It's Like a Rainbow of\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt did not give similar ground. She dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe former president's campaign announced Tuesday, hours ahead of Harris' rally, that he would travel to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same venue where Harris will appear on the Georgia State University campus.\n\nRelated Story: Roy Cooper Is Said to Withdraw From Harris' Vice-Presidential Field\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia. That approach was on display at the weekend office openings.\n\nOn Saturday, the venue was East Point, a majority Black municipality and Democratic stronghold south of Atlanta. Congressional Progressive Caucus Chair Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., was the featured guest, telling a crowd of mostly Black women that they were the key to victory -- \"the people who are really going to save the country.\"\n\nA day later, it was Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear, among several contenders Harris is considering for her running mate, campaigning in Forsyth County. The area is historically very conservative, though Democrats have narrowed the GOP margins in recent cycles.\n\n\"Every county matters,\" Beshear said, holding out his ability to win two governor's races in Kentucky despite Trump's domination of the state in presidential elections.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs, like those where Beshear campaigned on Sunday, offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nRelated Story: Harris Looks to Maintain Momentum as 'Honeymoon Phase' Winds Down\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.", "source": {"uri": "gvwire.com", "dataType": "news", "title": JD Vance (R-OH) speaks during a campaign rally at Middletown High School on July 22, 2024 in Middletown, Ohio. (Scott Olson/Getty Images)\n\nFormer President Donald Trump's running mate Sen. JD Vance, R-Ohio, privately admitted that Kamala Harris' presumptive Democratic nomination is a \"political sucker punch\" to the Trump campaign, The Washington Post reported.\n\nAhead of a rally in Minnesota on Saturday, Vance privately told GOP donors that Harris presents a unique challenge to the Republican Party, despite the Trump campaign exuding confidence since President Joe Biden's withdrawal from the race on July 21.\n\n\"All of us were hit with a little bit of a political sucker punch,\" Vance told donors at a fundraiser. \"The bad news is that Kamala Harris does not have the same baggage as Joe Biden, because whatever we might have to say, Kamala is a lot younger. And Kamala Harris is obviously not struggling in the same ways that Joe Biden did,\" Vance said.\n\nWhereas the public knew Biden's weaknesses, Vance said Harris is less known so the GOP would have to shape people's views of her.\n\n\"Love 'em or hate 'em, everybody has an opinion about Donald Trump and Joe Biden after the past eight years. But Kamala Harris, people don't really know,\" he told donors.\n\nDespite these admissions, Vance has previously told reporters that Harris' presumptive nomination doesn't change the presidential race.\n\n\"We were running against Joe Biden's open border, Kamala Harris's open border. Kamala Harris supported the green new scam. Kamala Harris, frankly, covered Joe Biden even though it was obvious he was mentally incompetent for a very long time,\" Vance told reporters on July 22, according to The Post.\n\nIn an interview with Fox News' Laura Ingraham on Monday, Trump said Harris was an \"even worse candidate'' than Biden because of her \"radical left\" policies.\n\nThe entire Trump campaign has doubled down on this message, pointing to Harris' flaws and remaining steadfast that she is a weak candidate.\n\n\"Poll after poll shows President Trump leading Kamala Harris as voters become aware of her weak, failed and dangerously liberal agenda. Her far-left ideas are even more radioactive than Joe Biden, particularly in the key swing states that will decide this election like Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin,\" said Vance spokesperson Will Martin in a statement to The Post on Monday.\n\nIn a New York Times/Sienna College poll from July 25, Trump currently leads Harris by one percentage point. He previously led Biden by six percentage points, before the president withdrew from November's presidential race.", "source": {"uri": "salon.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Salon.com"}, {"uri": "8249947894", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "04:54:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T04:54:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T04:52:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13686967/Democrats-feared-Georgia-lost-cause-Biden-running-Harris-campaign-Tuesday.html", "title": "Democrats had feared Georgia was a lost cause with Biden running....", "body": "ATLANTA (AP) - Little more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden 's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \" blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Vice President Kamala Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats say they have new hope for the state. They're betting that a fresh burst of energy and a surge in fundraising has helped make Georgia - the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 - a toss-up again.\n\nHarris is planning to make a show of political force with a rally in Atlanta on Tuesday night that will feature a performance by hip hop star Megan Thee Stallion, the latest example of just how much the race against Republican Donald Trump has shifted since Biden abandoned his reelection bid. She will be appearing in the same city where Biden's dismal performance in a debate against Trump on June 27 sparked a Democratic revolt that ultimately ended his campaign.\n\nHarris is hoping a large rally will help affirm her campaign's momentum. Her campaign argues that Harris\u00b4 appeal with young people, working-age women and non-white voters have scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O\u00b4Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nFILE - Vice President Kamala Harris speaks, Jan. 9, 2024, in Atlanta. With President Joe Biden having bowed out of the presidential race and endorsing Harris, their party is suddenly eyeing an expanding map, betting that a new burst of energy and fundraising surge has helped make Georgia, the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, a toss-up again. Harris is planning a show of political force on Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Atlanta, the latest example of just how much the presidential contest against Republican former President Donald Trump has changed. (AP Photo/Mike Stewart, File)\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden\u00b4s lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points - than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt did not give similar ground. She dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia. That approach was on display at the weekend office openings.\n\nOn Saturday, the venue was East Point, a majority Black municipality and Democratic stronghold south of Atlanta. Congressional Progressive Caucus Chair Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., was the featured guest, telling a crowd of mostly Black women that they were the key to victory - \"the people who are really going to save the country.\"\n\nA day later, it was Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear, among several contenders Harris is considering for her running mate, campaigning in Forsyth County. The area is historically very conservative, though Democrats have narrowed the GOP margins in recent cycles.\n\n\"Every county matters,\" Beshear said, holding out his ability to win two governor\u00b4s races in Kentucky despite Trump\u00b4s domination of the state in presidential elections.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts - combined with strong Democratic campaigns - lose.\n\nDemocrats recently have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs, like those where Beshear campaigned on Sunday, offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist - I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\nWeissert reported from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8251139575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:10:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:10:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:09:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.batimes.com.ar/news/world/harris-expands-push-to-compete-with-trump-in-swing-states.phtml", "title": "Harris expands push to compete with Trump in swing states", "body": "ice President Kamala Harris is kicking off a push to compete against Republican Donald Trump in a wider swath of battleground states with a Tuesday rally in Atlanta. Harris inherited a bleak electoral map from President Joe Biden. Before withdrawing from the race, polls showed the president trailing in nearly every swing state and his unpopularity largely confined him to a narrow path to victory dependent on holding a trio of key Great Lakes states.\n\nThe dynamic has shifted with Harris atop the ticket. Enjoying a burst of voter enthusiasm and campaign cash, the vice president is vying for Sun Belt states that Democrats had all but written off -- Georgia, Arizona and Nevada -- as well as the Democrats' so-called \"Blue Wall\" of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.\n\nHarris' event in Georgia's largest city is her first major effort to put a larger group of states back in play since launching her campaign on July 21. Rapper Megan Thee Stallion plans to make an appearance at the rally, she announced Monday on her Instagram account.\n\nHarris' campaign is confident that her relative popularity among key voting groups -- including women, younger voters and people of color -- has helped expand the electoral map, according to people familiar with their thinking. Those groups had drifted from Biden but have gravitated to the new presumptive Democratic nominee, who would become the first Black woman and Asian American president if she wins in November.\n\n\"The data is clear: We have multiple pathways to 270 electoral votes,\" Dan Kanninen, battleground director for the Harris campaign, told reporters on Monday. \"The vice president is strong in both the Blue Wall and in the Sun Belt, and we are running hard in both.\"\n\nEven before Biden's dramatic exit from the race, Harris had spent more time campaigning in the South and West than the president. Georgia is a state where the campaign sees that investment poised to pay off.\n\nThe vice president's visit to Georgia on Tuesday is her 15th since taking office and her campaign has bragged about its presence there, which includes 24 offices.\n\nA spending spree by Trump and his supporters indicates they, too, see Georgia as competitive. Trump and his allied super political action committee have booked $14.7 million in advertising there through the end of August, according to AdImpact, almost triple the $4.9 million that Future Forward PAC, which backs Harris, is set to spend.\n\nHarris' campaign on Tuesday launched a $50 million ad campaign in battleground states touting her background as a prosecutor. The announcement did not specify how much would be spent in Georgia.\n\nThe Trump campaign did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nTrump won Georgia by over 5 percentage points in 2016 but lost it to Biden four years later by less than a quarter of a point, the first time a Democratic nominee carried the Peach State in nearly three decades. The 2020 election left an indelible mark: Trump was indicted last year on state charges he sought to overturn his loss.\n\nTurning out Black voters in Atlanta will be crucial to Harris' chances.\n\nThe city has long been a magnet for people of color, with a cluster of historically Black colleges and universities that have been a pipeline for young professionals and a source of political activism. Harris attended Howard University, a prestigious historically Black college in Washington.\n\nAtlanta is a popular landing spot for members of the Divine Nine -- the most prominent Black fraternities and sororities -- whose network Harris has tapped as a member of Alpha Kappa Alpha. They offer her campaign an organic ground game in the state.\n\nRepresentative Nikema Williams, who also chairs the Georgia Democratic Party and will attend Harris' event, said her home state remains a \"true battleground.\"\n\n\"We're seeing the excitement on the ground, we're seeing people sign up to volunteer who haven't volunteered before,\" Williams said in an interview.\n\nAn Emerson College poll earlier in July when Biden was still in the race showed him trailing Trump in Georgia 47% to 41%. A poll taken after Harris' entry showed her narrowing the gap to 48% to 46%.\n\nBlue Wall\n\nBiden ended his bid after pressure from fellow Democrats alarmed by his calamitous debate against Trump. Polls showed the race moving in Trump's direction. The Republican gained an edge in many swing states and put places Biden carried easily in 2020, such as Minnesota and Virginia, into play.\n\n\"He was expanding the map into states that Democrats really had no business losing in,\" said Amy Walter, publisher of the nonpartisan Cook Political Report. Harris \"took what was a rapidly expanding map, which was benefiting Trump, and has narrowed it back to the battleground states.\"\n\nWith Biden atop the ticket, Democrats viewed the Blue Wall states as his best path to reelection. The president often touted his pro-union stance in an effort to win over White, working-class voters.\n\nHigh inflation, however, has overshadowed Biden's investments in domestic manufacturing and infrastructure. Broad voter skepticism over the administration's handling of the economy also threatens to undercut Harris' campaign.\n\nKanninen, the battleground director, said in an interview there is no indication Harris is performing worse across the Blue Wall.\n\n\"We've seen no data to suggest a backslide whatsoever,\" he said. \"The theory of the case has been win close races across several geographies and have the resources to do it.\"\n\nHarris' campaign has enrolled at least 170,000 new volunteers since Biden endorsed her, including over 50,000 in the battleground states, Kanninen said.\n\nDemocrats also have renewed hopes of competing in Nevada, a state with a relatively young electorate with large Black, Latino and Asian and Pacific Islander populations.\n\n\"When it comes to turning out must-win constituencies, energizing young voters and connecting with Nevada families on the issues that matter to them, Vice President Harris has already begun working to win and earn and their vote,\" said Molly Forgey, a Democratic campaign operative in the state.\n\nThe party saw a surge of interest there when Biden endorsed Harris, a Democratic campaign official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. About 600 new volunteers signed up that day. Harris also has cultivated ties with Nevada labor groups, including the powerful Culinary Workers Union most recently during a visit to Las Vegas in January.", "source": {"uri": "batimes.com.ar", {"uri": "2024-07-437597116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "22:01:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T22:01:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T21:58:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/07/29/jd-vance-kamala-harris-campaign/", "title": "Vance tells donors Harris change was a 'sucker punch,' at odds with campaign", "body": "Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.\n\nThe Republican vice-presidential nominee, Sen. JD Vance (R-Ohio), privately told donors that running against Vice President Harris instead of President Biden made the race more challenging -- an admission at odds with the Donald Trump campaign's public projections of confidence.\n\n\"All of us were hit with a little bit of a political sucker punch,\" Vance said about Biden's withdrawal on July 21, according to a recording of his remarks at a Saturday fundraiser in Golden Valley, Minn. \"The bad news is that Kamala Harris does not have the same baggage as Joe Biden, because whatever we might have to say, Kamala is a lot younger. And Kamala Harris is obviously not struggling in the same ways that Joe Biden did.\"\n\nPublicly, the Trump campaign has insisted that Harris replacing Biden at the top of the Democratic ticket has not changed the race, arguing that she shares responsibility for public dissatisfaction with Biden's leadership. Vance told reporters on July 22, a day after Biden dropped out of the race, that there was no difference in running against Harris versus Biden.\n\n\"I don't think the political calculus changes at all,\" Vance said. \"We were running against Joe Biden's open border, Kamala Harris's open border. Kamala Harris supported the green new scam. Kamala Harris, frankly, covered Joe Biden even though it was obvious he was mentally incompetent for a very long time.\"\n\nTrump adviser Jason Miller said in a July 22 Fox News interview: \"Democrats are a bit of jumping out of the frying pan into the fire. And they may have gotten rid of one problem with Joe Biden, but they've inherited a whole new problem with Kamala Harris.\"\n\nTrump himself has expressed nostalgia for running against Biden (\"He will always be my first choice\"), and at the same time dismissed Harris as \"worse than Joe.\"\n\nVance, though, gave a different assessment for donors on Saturday ahead of joining Trump at a rally in St. Cloud, Minn. He said Harris was less well-known than Trump or Biden, so Republicans would have to work to shape people's opinions of her.\n\n\"We have a very unique opportunity, but also a very unique challenge, because, let's be honest, 10 days ago, the two candidates who were running for president, everybody had an opinion about 'em. Love 'em or hate 'em, everybody has an opinion about Donald Trump and Joe Biden after the past eight years. But Kamala Harris, people don't really know.\"\n\nVance said the campaign would try to define Harris based on past positions, which he said included opposing fracking, praising the \"defund the police\" movement and supporting decriminalization of unauthorized border crossings. The Harris campaign says she won't ban fracking. She denounced \"defund the police\" after becoming Biden's running mate, and the current administration opposes decriminalizing border crossings.\n\nAt the fundraiser Vance recounted asking Trump's senior adviser Susie Wiles how the race had changed, and she answered that she was more confident Trump would win because people like Trump's polices better than Biden's.\n\nTwo national polls taken since Biden dropped out showed Trump and Harris within the margin of error, erasing Trump's earlier leads over Biden in the same surveys.\n\nVance spokesman Will Martin said Monday in a statement: \"Poll after poll shows President Trump leading Kamala Harris as voters become aware of her weak, failed and dangerously liberal agenda. Her far-left ideas are even more radioactive than Joe Biden, particularly in the key swing states that will decide this election like Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin.\"\n\nMeryl Kornfield {"uri": "8251045175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:56:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:56:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:56:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.dailycamera.com/2024/07/30/democrats-had-feared-georgia-was-a-lost-cause-with-biden-running-harris-will-campaign-there-tuesday/", "title": "Democrats had feared Georgia was a lost cause with Biden running. Harris will campaign there Tuesday", "body": "National Politics | Democrats had feared Georgia was a lost cause with Biden running. Harris will campaign there Tuesday\n\nBy WILL WEISSERT and BILL BARROW Associated Press\n\nATLANTA (AP) -- Little more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Vice President Kamala Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats say they have new hope for the state. They're betting that a fresh burst of energy and a surge in fundraising has helped make Georgia -- the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 -- a toss-up again.\n\nHarris is planning to make a show of political force with a rally in Atlanta at 7 p.m. ET on Tuesday, the latest example of just how much the race against Republican Donald Trump has shifted since Biden abandoned his reelection bid. She will be appearing in the same city where Biden's dismal performance in a debate against Trump on June 27 sparked a Democratic revolt that ultimately ended his campaign.\n\nHarris is hoping a large rally, featuring a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal with young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt did not give similar ground. She dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe former president's campaign announced Tuesday, hours ahead of Harris' rally, that he would travel to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same venue where Harris will appear on the Georgia State University campus.\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia. That approach was on display at the weekend office openings.\n\nOn Saturday, the venue was East Point, a majority Black municipality and Democratic stronghold south of Atlanta. Congressional Progressive Caucus Chair Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., was the featured guest, telling a crowd of mostly Black women that they were the key to victory -- \"the people who are really going to save the country.\"\n\nA day later, it was Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear, among several contenders Harris is considering for her running mate, campaigning in Forsyth County. The area is historically very conservative, though Democrats have narrowed the GOP margins in recent cycles.\n\n\"Every county matters,\" Beshear said, holding out his ability to win two governor's races in Kentucky despite Trump's domination of the state in presidential elections.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs, like those where Beshear campaigned on Sunday, offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.", "source": {"uri": "dailycamera.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Boulder Daily Camera"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251127436", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:01:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:01:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:00:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/the-latest-trump-claims-harris-married-to-a-jewish-man-doesnt-like-jewish-people/article_003103b0-0ce8-570e-bcf5-169e3e66ddb1.html", "title": "The Latest: Trump claims Harris, married to a Jewish man, doesn't like Jewish people", "body": "Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, left, and Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, center, arrive at a campaign event for Democratic presidential candidate Vice President Kamala Harris in Ambler, Pa., Monday, July 29, 2024.\n\nRepublican Donald Trump's campaign has announced that he will travel to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same venue where Democratic Vice President Kamala Harris plans one Tuesday night featuring a performance by hip hop star Megan Thee Stallion.\n\nDueling ad campaigns by the presidential candidates portray Harris as \"fearless,\" while an ad from Trump blasts the vice president for problems at the southern U.S. border.\n\nTrump also appears to be backing away from his earlier commitment to debate Harris, questioning the value of a meetup and saying that he \"probably\" will debate but that he \"can also make a case for not doing it\" -- prompting her campaign to say he's \"scared.\"\n\nAnd Senate lawmakers grilled the acting director of the Secret Service about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump.\n\nFollow the AP's Election-2024 coverage at: https://apnews.com/hub/election-2024.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nTrump says Harris, married to a Jewish man, doesn't like Jewish people\n\nFormer President Donald Trump said in a radio interview Tuesday that Vice President Kamala Harris, who is married to a Jewish man, \"doesn't like Jewish people\" and appeared to agree with a radio host who called second gentleman Doug Emhoff \"a crappy Jew.\"\n\nTrump, speaking on radio station WABC, claimed Harris looked uncomfortable while meeting last week with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.\n\n\"You can see the disdain,\" he said. \"No. 1, she doesn't like Israel. No. 2, she doesn't like Jewish people. You know it, I know it and everybody knows it, and nobody wants to say it.\"\n\nThe Republican former president then said, \"If you're Jewish, if you vote for a Democrat, you're a fool, an absolute fool. They have let Jewish people down since Obama at a level that nobody could believe.\"\n\nAs the interview went on, Trump again said Harris \"dislikes Jewish people.\" The interview host, Sid Rosenberg, then mentioned Emhoff and said, \"He's Jewish like Bernie Sanders is Jewish. Are you kidding me?\"\n\n\"Yeah,\" Trump said.\n\n\"He's a crappy Jew,\" Rosenberg said.\n\n\"Yeah,\" Trump said again.\n\nRosenberg went on, saying of Emhoff, \"He's a horrible Jew.\"\n\nJames Singer, a spokesperson for the Harris campaign, said, \"America is better than the fear, hate, and despicable insults of Donald Trump. Vice President Harris believes Americans want a president who unites our country instead of divides it, uses the power of the presidency to help families instead of hurt them, and has a vision for our future, instead of taking us backwards.\"\n\nHarris' potential running mates walk a fine line\n\nDemocratic governors and other officials under consideration to be Democrat Kamala Harris' vice presidential running mate are practicing a time-honored tradition in presidential campaigns. They're walking the line between open self-promotion and loyal advocacy for the potential boss in what amounts to unofficial auditions.\n\nPennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro campaigned for Harris on Monday outside Philadelphia. He blasted Republican former President Donald Trump and called Harris ready to lead. But he also showcased his own accomplishments.\n\nKentucky Gov. Andy Beshear took a similar approach over the weekend. He told voters in Georgia that Harris has the makings of \"a great president,\" and then highlighted the elections he has won as a Democrat in Republican territory.\n\nHarris is said to also be considering Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly, among others.\n\nSecret Service head, FBI's No. 2 grilled by Senate lawmakers\n\nThe acting director of the Secret Service said Tuesday he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe, testifying before two Senate committees, said that he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site where Trump had been holding a campaign rally, and that \"what I saw made me ashamed.\"\n\nRowe was joined at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official said a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nTrump plans rally at same Georgia venue as Harris event\n\nRepublican Donald Trump's campaign announced Tuesday, hours ahead of a rally planned by Vice President Kamala Harris at Georgia State University, that he will travel to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same venue.\n\nDemocrats say they have new hope for winning Georgia in November after President Joe Biden bowed out of the race and endorsed Harris. They're betting that a fresh burst of energy and a surge in fundraising has helped make Georgia -- the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 -- a toss-up again.\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nTrump ad blasts Harris for problems at the border\n\nRepublican candidate Donald Trump's campaign released a new advertisement Tuesday, blasting Vice President Kamala Harris for problems at the U.S. southern border.\n\nThe advertisement dubs Harris the \"border czar,\" a reference to her work on migration issues. It includes a parade of headlines about drugs and criminals entering the country, as well as a clip from a controversial interview that Harris did three years ago in which she brushed off a suggestion that she would visit the border.\n\n\"Failed. Weak. Dangerously liberal,\" the advertisement brands Harris.\n\nNew $50 million ad portrays Harris as 'fearless'\n\nVice President Kamala Harris' campaign is kickstarting a $50 million advertising campaign with a new television spot calling the likely Democratic presidential nominee \"fearless\" throughout her career.\n\n\"Throughout her career as a courtroom prosecutor, attorney general, United States senator, and now as vice president, Kamala Harris has always stood up to bullies, criminals and special interests on behalf of the American people - and she's beaten them,\" said a statement from Jen O'Malley Dillon, the campaign chair.\n\n\"She's uniquely suited to take on Donald Trump, a convicted felon who has spent his entire life ripping off working people, tearing away our rights, and fighting for himself.\"\n\nThe advertisement is slated to run during the Olympics, \"The Bachelorette,\" \"The Daily Show\" and other popular programs. It's an attempt to even the score with Republicans, who have been outspending Democrats on the airwaves during a chaotic summer when President Joe Biden ended his reelection bid and endorsed Harris.\n\nRapper Megan Thee Stallion to campaign for Harris\n\nRapper Megan Thee Stallion will join Vice President Kamala Harris for a special performance during her campaign stop in Atlanta on Tuesday.\n\nA Harris campaign spokesperson confirmed the hip-hop star's performance alongside the vice president in a post on X on Monday night.\n\nThe Harris campaign is promising a large rally in Atlanta, on par with the large events that Republican former President Donald Trump has made his signature.\n\nHarris has America focused on multiracial identity\n\nIf Vice President Kamala Harris were to ascend to the presidency, she would become the first female president, but also one who is also multiracial.\n\nThe daughter of a Jamaican father and an Indian mother, both of whom immigrated to the U.S. during the Civil Rights Movement, Harris' historic presidential bid has again put a spotlight on American identity politics and the growing number of people who say they are multiracial.\n\nDifferent countries divide people into categories depending on different national traditions. The U.S., with its slavery-molded history, divides people into Black or white, and nine million people identified as multiracial in 2010.\n\nWhen Harris ran for vice president in 2020, 33.8 million people in the U.S. identified as being more than one race, according to the census.", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8249374013", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "18:05:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T18:05:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:04:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://lavocedinewyork.com/en/news/2024/07/29/new-polls-show-harris-gains-on-trump-with-strong-support-from-voters/", "title": "New Polls Show Harris Gains on Trump with Strong Support from Voters", "body": "US Vice President Kamala Harris addresses the American Federation of Teachers' 88th national convention during her keynote speech in Houston, Texas, USA, 25 July 2024. US President Joe Biden announced on 21 July he would not seek re-election and endorsed Vice President Harris to be the Democratic Party's new nominee for the US elections in November 2024. EPA/LESLIE PLAZA JOHNSON\n\nRecent polls conducted by numerous outlets have found that Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are neck and neck in terms of support from Americans, closing the gap the Republican nominee held over President Joe Biden.\n\nSince Biden withdrew from the race, Harris' support from many voters has considerably increased, indicating she has broken into the six-point lead Trump previously had over the president since the debate that they held. According to a poll issued by the Wall Street Journal, Trump now holds just a 2% lead over Harris in a two-person race, within the Journal's 3.1% margin of error.\n\nOther polls conducted this week by The New York Times/Siena College (Trump +1 over Harris) and CNN (Trump +3) also represent tightening from a 6-point Trump leads, a shift that followed the assassination attempt, his selection of Sen. JD Vance (R-Ohio) as his running mate, and the GOP convention. Those events were all expected to give Trump a considerable boost, instead he seems to be losing ground. Harris is trailing closely behind the Republican nominee, performing rather well with traditionally Democratic groups among whom Biden was not overwhelmingly favored.\n\n\"Only 37% of Biden voters were enthusiastic about him in early July, and now 81% of Harris voters are enthusiastic about her,\" Democratic pollster Mike Bocian, who conducted the WSJ survey with Republican pollster David Lee, told the Journal. \"This is an astounding change.\"\n\nThe Times/Siena poll found Harris is running stronger than Biden has all year among young voters and minority voters, while also maintaining support from older and white voters, a demographic where his numbers were strong. Yet, the results also show the former president is running ahead of his 2016 and 2020 numbers within those groups.\n\nMeanwhile, an Axios/Generation Lab poll conducted this week among voters aged 18-34 showed Harris leading Trump by 20 points, 60% to 40%, compared to Biden's 6% lead. Some 45% among the cohort said they had a positive opinion of Harris, compared with 33% who said the same about Biden, and 34% who felt positively about Trump.\n\nAn aggregate of polls from the Hill and Decision Desk HQ, based on 80 polls, has Trump at 47.8% to 45.7% for Harris, a difference again within the margin of error that could reflect they are actually tied.\n\nSince Harris announced she would run in place of Biden, she has raised $200 million from donors, marking one of the largest fundraising periods in presidential history. He has called on Congress to quickly establish term limits and an enforceable ethics code for the court's nine justices. He also called on lawmakers to ratify a constitutional amendment limiting presidential immunity.\n\nThe FBI says former President Donald Trump has agreed to be interviewed as part of the investigation into the assassination attempt in Pennsylvania this month.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris' campaign raised $200 million since she emerged as the likely Democratic presidential nominee last week, an eyepopping haul in her race against former President Trump.\n\nFollow the AP's Election-2024 coverage at: https://apnews.com/hub/election-2024.\n\nHere's the Latest:\n\nTrump ad blames Harris for problems at the border\n\nRepublican candidate Donald Trump's campaign released a new advertisement Tuesday, blasting Vice President Kamala Harris for problems at the U.S. southern border.\n\nThe advertisement dubs Harris the \"border czar,\" a reference to her work on migration issues. It includes a parade of headlines about drugs and criminals entering the country, as well as a clip from a controversial interview that Harris did three years ago in which she brushed off a suggestion that she would visit the border.\n\n\"Failed. Weak. Dangerously liberal,\" the advertisement brands Harris.\n\nNew $50 million ad portrays Harris as 'fearless'\n\nVice President Kamala Harris' campaign is kickstarting a $50 million advertising campaign with a new television spot calling the likely Democratic presidential nominee \"fearless\" throughout her career.\n\n\"Throughout her career as a courtroom prosecutor, attorney general, United States senator, and now as vice president, Kamala Harris has always stood up to bullies, criminals and special interests on behalf of the American people - and she's beaten them,\" said a statement from Jen O'Malley Dillon, the campaign chair.\n\n\"She's uniquely suited to take on Donald Trump, a convicted felon who has spent his entire life ripping off working people, tearing away our rights, and fighting for himself.\"\n\nThe advertisement is slated to run during the Olympics, \"The Bachelorette,\" \"The Daily Show\" and other popular programs. It's an attempt to even the score with Republicans, who have been outspending Democrats on the airwaves during a chaotic summer when President Joe Biden ended his reelection bid and endorsed Harris.\n\nRapper Megan Thee Stallion to campaign for Harris\n\nRapper Megan Thee Stallion will join Vice President Kamala Harris for a special performance during her campaign stop in Atlanta on Tuesday.\n\nA Harris campaign spokesperson confirmed the hip-hop star's performance alongside the vice president in a post on X on Monday night.\n\nThe Harris campaign is promising a large rally in Atlanta, on par with the large events that Republican former President Donald Trump has made his signature.\n\nHarris has America focused on multiracial identity\n\nIf Vice President Kamala Harris were to ascend to the presidency, she would become the first female president, but also one who is also multiracial.\n\nThe daughter of a Jamaican father and an Indian mother, both of whom immigrated to the U.S. during the Civil Rights Movement, Harris' historic presidential bid has again put a spotlight on American identity politics and the growing number of people who say they are multiracial.\n\nDifferent countries divide people into categories depending on different national traditions. The U.S., with its slavery-molded history, divides people into Black or white, and nine million people identified as multiracial in 2010.\n\nWhen Harris ran for vice president in 2020, 33.8 million people in the U.S. identified as being more than one race, according to the census.\n\nMore from this section\n\nPIC's WooSOS Plugin Streamlines Ecommerce Through WooCommerce and SOS Inventory Vance, as he holds a rally for the first time with his running mate, in Grand Rapids, Michigan, U.S. July 20. (Reuters)\n\nDonald Trump on Monday backed his running mate JD Vance over past comments about \"childless cat ladies,\" which criticised Vice President Kamala Harris and have since gone viral.\n\nVance's 2021 comments about Democrats resurfaced after Trump selected the Ohio senator as his running mate earlier this month. Harris is the likely Democratic Party presidential nominee for the Nov. 5 election following President Joe Biden's decision to quit the race.\n\nIn an interview on Fox News, Republican presidential candidate Trump said he did not place a higher value on people with families. \"You know, you don't meet the right person, or you don't meet any person. But you're just as good, in many cases, a lot better than a person that's in a family situation,\" Trump said.\n\nTrump said Vance, who had a tough upbringing in Ohio and was largely raised by his grandmother, was simply trying to show how much he values family life. \"He grew up in a very interesting family situation, and he feels family is good. And I don't think there's anything wrong in saying that,\" Trump said.\n\nThis interview comes as Trump's campaign is expected to launch a $10 million advertising blitz in six battleground states this week as it tries to counter a surge of voter enthusiasm and donations for his Democratic rival. It is Trump's biggest ad buy since January, when he was fighting off Republican rivals for the party's nomination. Trump's campaign did not respond to requests for comment, but the blitz comes as Harris' candidacy has changed the race.\n\nSince Joe Biden dropped out last week and endorsed Harris, she has rapidly consolidated support within the Democratic Party and from big-money donors. She has also sparked a newfound energy among groups such as young voters that Biden had been struggling to win over. After months of attacks on Biden's fitness for office, Trump's campaign has had to pivot to find a new message to use against Harris, 59, less than 100 days until the Nov. 5 election.\n\nOn Monday, Trump, 78, released an ad on his Truth Social platform using Harris's own words from old interviews, campaign events and debates to try to portray her as an extreme liberal out of touch with everyday Americans. {"uri": "8251049260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:00:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:00:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:59:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/democrats-target-georgia-megan-thee-stallion-give-kamala-harris-star-appeal-1932160", "title": "Democrats target Georgia as Megan Thee Stallion gives Harris star appeal", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris is set to hold a presidential campaign rally on Tuesday in Georgia, a battleground state Democrats are aiming to target with renewed hope.\n\nDemocrats have quickly rallied behind Harris after President Joe Biden announced that he was dropping out of the 2024 race a little over a week ago.\n\nOn Tuesday, Harris is set to demonstrate her campaign strategy with a high-profile rally in Atlanta. The rally marks a shift in the race against former President Donald Trump, as Harris aims to galvanize support with a star-studded event featuring a performance by rapper Megan Thee Stallion, reflecting her campaign's focus on appealing to young, working-age, and nonwhite voters across Georgia and similar states.\n\nMegan Thee Stallion joins a host of musicians who have recently come out in support of Harris as she has also earned endorsements from several pop-culture stars, including British artist Charli XCX, whose latest album Brat has become a branding tool for the vice president's campaign.\n\nNewsweek has reached out to Harris' campaign via email for comment.\n\nHowever, this comes after Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, had a wave of public figures show their support for his reelection campaign during the Republican National Convention this month. Model and rapper Amber Rose gave a passionate speech endorsing Trump on the first day of the convention, and singer and rapper Kid Rock performed his hit American Bad Ass before the former president gave his keynote address on the last day of the event.\n\nMeanwhile, according to The Associated Press, the Democratic Party is now seeing renewed hope in Georgia, fueled by a surge in fundraising and energy as battleground states will continue to play a key role in determining the election due to the Electoral College, which awards each state a certain number of electoral votes based on population.\n\nA presidential candidate needs to secure 270 electoral votes for victory, and winning the national popular vote does not guarantee success.\n\nIn a strategy memo post-Biden's exit, Harris' campaign chair, Jen O'Malley Dillon, emphasized the continued importance of other battleground states such as Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania as she argued that Harris \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" including \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under-30\" voters in states like Georgia, the AP reported.\n\nIn addition, Democrats have ramped up their presence in Georgia with 24 campaign offices, including new additions in the metro Atlanta area as the Democratic strategy focuses on making gains in suburban areas.\n\nThe campaign offices come as Trump and the Republican National Committee have also recently opened their first Georgia offices.\n\nHowever, according to AP, Republicans remain skeptical, arguing that Harris inherits Biden's low approval ratings and voter concerns over economic issues and immigration as they aim to take back the state after the tight contest of 2020 when Biden won by a slim margin of 0.25 percentage points.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" GOP consultant Brian Robinson told AP. \"Now, Democrats have a chance for a reset.\"\n\nNewsweek has reached out to Trump's campaign via email for comment.\n\nMeanwhile, the momentum behind Harris has helped Democrats close the gap on Trump and Republicans in national polling. Voter surveys have also shown the former president's lead shrink in key swing states like Georgia, which Biden flipped in the 2020 election when he defeated Trump.\n\nAccording to a recent poll by Landmark Communications, Trump was trailing Harris by 1.3 percentage points (48% to 46.7%) in a hypothetical head-to-head match among likely voters in the Peach State. {"uri": "8251096102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:36:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:36:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:35:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://baynews9.com/fl/tampa/news/2024/07/30/trump-harris-new-campaign-ads-2024-election-immigration-border-", "title": "Trump, Harris out with new ads as both look to shape race", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump on Tuesday both released fresh TV advertisements as the competing campaigns look to find their footing in a dramatically changed -- and bound to be contentious -- presidential election in just 98 days.\n\nThe new ads from both sides focus on the vice president and come after President Joe Biden's decision to drop his reelection bid and endorse Harris, setting off a race to shape the narrative around the new candidate likely to be the Democratic presidential nominee.\n\nThe ad from the Harris campaign, called \"Fearless,\" highlights the vice president's history as a courtroom prosecutor and attorney general of California, noting she \"put murders and abusers behind bars\" and took on big banks.\n\n\"Because Kamala Harris has always known who she represents,\" the ad continues, before going on to accuse Trump of wanting to \"take our country backward,\" building on a theme Harris has sought to establish during her first week on the trail when she has often said the election is about a vision for the future versus the past.\n\n\"But we are not going back,\" the ad concludes in Harris' voice.\n\n\"Throughout her career as a courtroom prosecutor, Attorney General, United States Senator, and now as Vice President, Kamala Harris has always stood up to bullies, criminals and special interests on behalf of the American people - and she's beaten them,\" Harris' campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon said in a statement. \"She's uniquely suited to take on Donald Trump, a convicted felon who has spent his entire life ripping off working people, tearing away our rights, and fighting for himself.\"\n\nThe one-minute spot will run during the Olympics Games and other programming such as The Bachelorette, The Daily Show and Love & Hip Hop, according to Harris' team. It's the first ad in the Harris campaign's new $50 million battleground state paid media blitz ahead of the Democratic National Convention, set to kick off on Aug. 19.\n\nTrump's team on Tuesday, on the other hand, released its first major TV ad targeting Harris just over a week since she became Democrats' likely nominee.\n\nThe 30-second spot seeks to hit the vice president on immigration and the southern border, starting with a video of her dancing and referring to her as \"America's border czar,\" a phrase Republicans have latched onto to criticize Harris and one Democrats have sought to aggressively push back against. Biden tasked Harris, his vice president, with leading the charge to tackle the root causes of migration.\n\nThe ad goes on to say that under the vice president, \"over 10 million [are] illegally here\" and \"a quarter of a million Americans [are] dead from fentanyl.\"\n\nThe spot then highlights an interview Harris did with NBC News' Lester Holt three years ago in which the anchor pressed the vice president on criticism for not visiting the border.\n\n\"Kamala Harris. Failed. Weak. Dangerously liberal,\" the ad concludes with the words appearing on the screen.\n\nThe ad is part of a $12 million reservation the Trump team has made through Aug. 12 across the six biggest swing states, according to AdImpact, a firm that tracks data on advertisements.\n\nBoth ads out on Tuesday build on storylies the campaigns have already sought to establish in just the first week since it appeared likely that it would be Trump and Harris facing off in November.\n\nThe vice president has pointed to her background as a prosecutor and contrasted it with Trump's legal troubles, including the guilty verdict in his New York hush money trial in May. Trump has often pointed to the Biden-Harris administration's handling of the border as polls show the issue has surged in importance to voters.\n\nArrests for illegal border crossings hit all-time highs during Biden and Harris' time in office. Encounters have significantly dropped in recent weeks after Biden signed took executive action to put restrictions on asylum.", "source": {"uri": "baynews9.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Spectrum {"uri": "2024-07-438410832", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:16:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:16:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:09:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/nation-world/national/article290567234.html", "title": "Harris team expands push to compete with Trump in swing states", "body": "By Josh Wingrove and Akayla Gardner, Bloomberg News The Tribune Content Agency\n\nVice President Kamala Harris is kicking off a push to compete against Republican Donald Trump in a wider swath of battleground states with a Tuesday rally in Atlanta.\n\nHarris inherited a bleak electoral map from President Joe Biden. Before withdrawing from the race, polls showed the president trailing in nearly every swing state and his unpopularity largely confined him to a narrow path to victory dependent on holding a trio of key Great Lakes states.\n\nThe dynamic has shifted with Harris atop the ticket. Enjoying a burst of voter enthusiasm and campaign cash, the vice president is vying for Sun Belt states that Democrats had all but written off - Georgia, Arizona and Nevada - as well as the Democrats' so-called \"Blue Wall\" of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.\n\nHarris' event in Georgia's largest city is her first major effort to put a larger group of states back in play since launching her campaign on July 21. Rapper Megan Thee Stallion plans to make an appearance at the rally, she announced Monday on her Instagram account.\n\nHarris' campaign is confident that her relative popularity among key voting groups - including women, younger voters and people of color - has helped expand the electoral map, according to people familiar with their thinking. Those groups had drifted from Biden but have gravitated to the new presumptive Democratic nominee, who would become the first Black woman and Asian American president if she wins in November.\n\n\"The data is clear: We have multiple pathways to 270 electoral votes,\" Dan Kanninen, battleground director for the Harris campaign, told reporters on Monday. \"The vice president is strong in both the Blue Wall and in the Sun Belt, and we are running hard in both.\"\n\nGeorgia Battleground\n\nEven before Biden's dramatic exit from the race, Harris had spent more time campaigning in the South and West than the president. Georgia is a state where the campaign sees that investment poised to pay off.\n\nThe vice president's visit to Georgia on Tuesday is her 15th since taking office and her campaign has bragged about its presence there, which includes 24 offices.\n\nA spending spree by Trump and his supporters indicates they, too, see Georgia as competitive. Trump and his allied super political action committee have booked $14.7 million in advertising there through the end of August, according to AdImpact, almost triple the $4.9 million that Future Forward PAC, which backs Harris, is set to spend. The vice president's campaign has not reserved any advertising time in the state.\n\nThe Trump campaign did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nTrump won Georgia by over 5 percentage points in 2016 but lost it to Biden four years later by less than a quarter of a point, the first time a Democratic nominee carried the Peach State in nearly three decades. The 2020 election left an indelible mark: Trump was indicted last year on state charges he sought to overturn his loss.\n\nTurning out Black voters in Atlanta will be crucial to Harris' chances.\n\nThe city has long been a magnet for people of color, with a cluster of historically Black colleges and universities that have been a pipeline for young professionals and a source of political activism. Harris attended Howard University, a prestigious historically Black college in Washington.\n\nAtlanta is a popular landing spot for members of the Divine Nine - the most prominent Black fraternities and sororities - whose network Harris has tapped as a member of Alpha Kappa Alpha. They offer her campaign an organic ground game in the state.\n\nRepresentative Nikema Williams, who also chairs the Georgia Democratic Party and will attend Harris' event, said her home state remains a \"true battleground.\"\n\n\"We're seeing the excitement on the ground, we're seeing people sign up to volunteer who haven't volunteered before,\" Williams said in an interview.\n\nAn Emerson College poll earlier in July when Biden was still in the race showed him trailing Trump in Georgia 47% to 41%. A poll taken after Harris' entry showed her narrowing the gap to 48% to 46%.\n\nBlue Wall\n\nBiden ended his bid after pressure from fellow Democrats alarmed by his calamitous debate against Trump. Polls showed the race moving in Trump's direction. The Republican gained an edge in many swing states and put places Biden carried easily in 2020, such as Minnesota and Virginia, into play.\n\n\"He was expanding the map into states that Democrats really had no business losing in,\" said Amy Walter, publisher of the nonpartisan Cook Political Report. Harris \"took what was a rapidly expanding map, which was benefiting Trump, and has narrowed it back to the battleground states.\"\n\nWith Biden atop the ticket, Democrats viewed the Blue Wall states as his best path to reelection. The president often touted his pro-union stance in an effort to win over White, working-class voters.\n\nHigh inflation, however, has overshadowed Biden's investments in domestic manufacturing and infrastructure. Broad voter skepticism over the administration's handling of the economy also threatens to undercut Harris' campaign.\n\nKanninen, the battleground director, said in an interview there is no indication Harris is performing worse across the Blue Wall.\n\n\"We've seen no data to suggest a backslide whatsoever,\" he said. \"The theory of the case has been win close races across several geographies and have the resources to do it.\"\n\nDemocratic Surge\n\nHarris' campaign has enrolled at least 170,000 new volunteers since Biden endorsed her, including over 50,000 in the battleground states, Kanninen said.\n\nDemocrats also have renewed hopes of competing in Nevada, a state with a relatively young electorate with large Black, Latino and Asian and Pacific Islander populations.\n\n\"When it comes to turning out must-win constituencies, energizing young voters and connecting with Nevada families on the issues that matter to them, Vice President Harris has already begun working to win and earn and their vote,\" said Molly Forgey, a Democratic campaign operative in the state.\n\nThe party saw a surge of interest there when Biden endorsed Harris, a Democratic campaign official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. About 600 new volunteers signed up that day. Harris also has cultivated ties with Nevada labor groups, including the powerful Culinary Workers Union most recently during a visit to Las Vegas in January.\n\n-With assistance from Hadriana And Kamala Harris is obviously not struggling in the same ways that Joe Biden did,\" he added.\n\nVance's private comments appear to be the first time the VP contender has recognized Harris has a much stronger campaign than Biden - one that could shake up the current political landscape.\n\nPublicly, Vance has said differently, telling reporters on July 22, \"I don't think the political calculus changes at all.\"\n\nThe Independent has reached out to a spokesperson for Vance for comment.\n\nOn the campaign trail, Vance has launched attacks against Harris, claiming she \"lied\" about Biden's health before he dropped out of the 2024 presidential race, criticizing her for supporting clean energy alternatives, failing to address and fix the border crisis and more.\n\nDonald Trump has used similar rhetoric, telling CBS News that Harris is \"no better\" than Biden and \"could be far less competent.\"\n\nThe Trump campaign has maintained a confident image since the Democratic candidate shake-up, pointing to polling that shows Trump polling ahead in key swing states.\n\nIn a statement provided to The Washington Post, a spokesperson for Vance said, \"Poll after poll shows President Trump leading Kamala Harris as voters become aware of her weak, failed and dangerously liberal agenda. Her far-left ideas are even more radioactive than Joe Biden, particularly in the key swing states that will decide this election like Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin.\"\n\nAlthough Trump is polling ahead, since entering the race Harris has narrowed the gap between her and the Republican nominee. "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/news/12052735/kamala-harris-honeymoon-poll-donald-trump-president/", "title": "'Harris Honeymoon' is already ending as voters say Kamala is 'less qualified'", "body": "THE honeymoon phase is over as voters are quickly losing faith in Kamala Harris' chances at beating out Donald Trump in the upcoming presidential election.\n\nNearly a third of voters believe Harris is much less qualified than other potential nominees to be the Democratic presidential candidate, according to new polling by The U.S. Sun.\n\nThe U.S. Sun's survey of 1,000 people, conducted by Talker Research, revealed that only a quarter of Americans feel that Harris is much more qualified than other candidates to be the party nominee.\n\nWhile 29% of the surveyed group believe that she's \"much less qualified,\" feelings were split across party lines as only 15% of Republicans believe that Harris is more qualified to be the candidate compared to other potential nominees.\n\nHowever, no other Democratic party candidates have stepped forward to challenge Harris' bid.\n\nOver a third of respondents think it's \"very unlikely\" that Harris can beat out former President Trump, while only 26% think that she is very likely to overtake him.\n\nThis skepticism marks the end of Harris' honeymoon phase with voters, which saw her raise over $200 million in the first week after it was announced she would run for president in place of President Joe Biden when he dropped out of the race on July 21.\n\nTrump campaign Tony Fabrizio branded the \"Harris honeymoon\" when he warned campaign staffers about the VP taking the lead in the polls after it was announced that she'd be joining the race.\n\n\"The honeymoon will be a manifestation of the wall-to-wall coverage Harris receives from the [mainstream media,]\" he wrote to staff in a memo, according to Newsweek.\n\nFabrizio said the bump from media coverage would \"energize Democrats\" but that it would drop again once the \"race settles back down.\"\n\n\"Before long, Harris' 'honeymoon' will end and voters will refocus on her role as Biden's partner and co-pilot,\" Fabrizio wrote.\n\nThe honeymoon phase seems to be continuing for some voters in the polls despite doubts about Harris' qualifications and her chances at winning.\n\nNow that Biden has withdrawn from the election, the poll revealed that 45% of Americans are planning to vote for Trump - while Harris beating him by a hair with 46% of respondents planning to vote for her.\n\nWhile over three quarters (77%) of Democrats think that Harris can defeat Trump, only 14% of Republicans think it's possible.\n\nOverall, a slightly larger amount of Americans have a positive view of Harris than a negative one, the polling numbers report.\n\nThe survey also showed that while only 10% of Republicans have a positive view of the VP, third party members have a more positive than negative view.\n\nBiden tapped Harris to take his spot almost immediately after stepping down following weeks of backlash over his disastrous performance in the first debate of the season against Trump on June 27.\n\nHis resignation came as over 30 Democrat leaders had publicly called for him to step down, starting with Texas Representative Lloyd Doggett telling Biden to withdraw on July 2.\n\nA group of at least 50 moderate Capitol Hill Democrats then held a concerning Zoom call with Biden where they expressed worries about his ability to continue in the race - just hours before the July 13 assassination attempt on Trump.\n\nAfter maintaining a \"full speed ahead\" effort throughout his campaign, Biden told a senior member of his team about his decision to suspend his campaign just one minute before news of his exit broke on July 21.\n\nHe then wrote on X that he would endorse Harris, his running mate, as the Democrat nominee.\n\n\"But we couldn't be more excited for her -- or more thrilled to endorse Kamala Harris as the Democratic nominee for President of the United States.\"\n\nHarris graciously accepted the endorsement in a separate statement and promised to \"earn the nomination,\" praising Biden's tenure as president.\n\nThe presidential hopeful secured 2,668 delegates just a day after Biden's withdrawal.\n\nShe raised a record $81 million in donations in the first 24 hours of her campaign. She also inherited some $91 million in leftover campaign funds from Biden.\n\nThe Democrats will officially nominate the party's candidate at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, Illinois starting on August 19.\n\nIt comes as:\n\nSpeculation continues to swirl about who Harris could name as her vice president pick as the poll revealed that 42% of Americans are simply unsure about who the running mate could be.\n\nPotential names thrown into the running have included North Carolina governor Roy Cooper, Pennsylvania's governor Josh Shapiro, and Michigan's governor Gretchen Whitmer.\n\nHarris is reportedly set to announce her running partner by August 7, according to The New York Times.", "source": {"uri": "the-sun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The US Sun"},
