{"uri": "2024-07-437916482", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "07:11:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T07:11:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T07:06:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3843137323856354, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/opinion/bidens-coup-for-a-coup-to-avenge-his-ouster-from-white-house-race-13798622.html", "title": "Biden's 'coup for a coup' to avenge his ouster from White House race", "body": "The US President didn't 'pass the torch to a new generation'. By endorsing Kamala Harris, he seemed to have settled a score with top Democrats who forced him out of the contest read more\n\nStumbling, snoring, jumbling, jabbering, bumbling and bungling, US President Joe Biden had become the perfect example of brain fog. Mixing up names, tripping over, napping and blabbering at domestic and international summits, pressers or events, disorientation had become his middle name.\n\nThe blooper-in-chief's desperate bit for a second shot at the White House ended in the catastrophic debate with his challenger and predecessor Donald Trump on June 27.\n\nYouGov poll after Biden's disastrous debate performance and before the Trump assassination bid found him trailing his rival in all seven battleground states -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- six of which he won in 2020. The poll, conducted between July 4 and July 12, showed Biden's significant decline from his position in the states since March.\n\nFrustrated and angry, wealthy Democratic donors realised they had bet on an old horse. The donors told Future Forward, the largest pro-Biden super political action committee, that pledges worth around $90 million were on hold unless he exited. The donors coined the slogan \"No more dough until no more Joe, signalling their desperation.\n\nA few hours before Biden quit the race, the number of Congress Democrats who wanted him to step down had grown to 37, including senators Joe Manchin, Sherrod Brown, Peter Welch and Martin Heinrich and representatives Mark Takano, Marc Veasey, Jared Huffman, Chuy Garcia and Mark Pocan. Even his former boss and president, Barack Obama, wanted him to pull out.\n\nHowever, despite polls showing him behind Trump, more Democrats asking him to withdraw, and donors refusing to pump more money, Biden's delusion of self-grandeur continued for 23 days. He wasn't honest enough to admit the bitter reality staring at his face -- frailty and mental aberrations bordering on schizophrenia that could have derailed the Democratic Party.\n\nIn interviews with two radio stations, WURD Radio in Philadelphia and Civic Media in Milwaukee, he admitted his poor performance but dug his heels.\n\nIn an exclusive interview with ABC News, he said that only \"if the Lord Almighty comes down and tells me that [to stand down], I might do that\" though he acknowledged that the debate was a \"bad episode\".\n\nThe last straw was Biden testing positive for Covid on July 18. As he self-isolated at his Rehoboth Beach home in Delaware, his two confidantes, Steve Ricchetti and Mike Donilon, landed there with the bad news on July 20.\n\nBiden campaign polls, according to them, showed that Biden's re-election chances had evaporated.\n\nParty stalwart and former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi played a major role in Biden's exit by giving almost an ultimatum as more Democratic lawmakers were planning to ask him to withdraw. Pelosi had the support of Senate majority leader Chuck Schumer and House minority leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nAn enraged and frustrated Biden realised that game was over. On July 21, he dropped the bomb by posting a letter on X.\n\nDemocrats praised Biden for the 'selfless' decision to withdraw and his service to the nation, but it was a pathetic face-saving attempt. The commentariat and the average Joe knew why Biden hung up his boots -- he was mentally and physically unfit and the pressure exerted by dissident Democrats to withdraw was unbearable.\n\nBiden misled the public with big words\n\nIn his July 24 address to the nation explaining his withdrawal, the 46th POTUS told Americans that he quit the race in the \"defence of democracy\" and passed \"the torch to a new generation\".\n\nInvoking patriotism, he said, \"I revere this office, but I love my country more. It's been the honour of my life to serve as your president. But in the defence of democracy, which is at stake, I think it's more important than any title. We have to decide: Do we still believe in honesty, decency and respect; freedom, justice and democracy?\"\n\nIn his fantastical leap of self-importance and ambition, he refused to admit his worst judgement. \"I believe my record as president, my leadership in the world, my vision for America's future, all merited a second term.\"\n\nBiden's 'coup for a coup'\n\nBiden was literally forced to hang up his boots around 100 days before the election -- his anger, resentment, frustration and revenge were natural.\n\nHis wife, Jill, and son, Hunter, seethed with rage at top Democrats who orchestrated his ouster. The First Lady felt his cataclysmic debate performance was \" a great job\" and was \" all in for his decision to fight Trump despite the opposition in the party.\n\nA source close to the Biden family told the New York Post that top Democrats threatened to invoke the 25th Amendment of the US Constitution and urge vice-president (V-P) Kamala Harris and the Cabinet to remove Biden from office.\n\nBiden's rage was at a different level. Still hallucinating about a second term, he couldn't fathom the reality. He had enough. He devised a strategy to assert some control over the party by planning his own 'coup'.\n\nInitially, Biden hadn't endorsed Harris as the party's nominee in the letter posted on X at 11.16 pm. But at 11.43 pm, he endorsed her in another post.\n\nWhat transpired in those 27 minutes to make Biden endorse Harris isn't known.\n\nOn July 26, the Post reported that Biden's endorsement of Harris was his revenge on top Dems, including Obama, who had told allies that his chances of a second victory had drastically diminished.\n\n\"It was Joe's big fu*k you. Joe said, 'If I'm out, then I am endorsing her,'\" the source close to the Biden family told the Post claiming that Obama had asked the president to allow delegates at August's Democratic National Convention in Chicago to decide a new nominee.\n\nBiden's endorsement of Harris was one step ahead of the late President Lyndon B Johnson's behind-the-scenes game before the 1968 presidential election.\n\nJohnson's primary challengers were senators Eugene McCarthy and Robert F Kennedy. On March 21, 1968, Johnson announced that he wouldn't contest after only barely winning the New Hampshire primary.\n\nShockingly, the game changed after V-P Hubert Humphrey entered into the race without competing in any of the 13 primaries, inherited the delegates pledged to Johnson and collected delegates in caucus states, especially in those controlled by local Democratic leaders like Chicago mayor Ruchard Daley. He bagged the nomination due to the tight control of Johnson and other major leaders over the Democratic National Convention (DNC).\n\nSeveral Democrats saw the process of nominee selection at the party convention, not through primaries and caucuses, undemocratic. Therefore, both Democrats and Republicans have been selecting their nominees through primaries and caucuses since 1972.\n\nThough the convention system in both parties have nominated great leaders like Abraham Lincoln, Ulysses S Grant, Woodrow Wilson, FDR, Dwight D Eisenhower and JFK, who were elected president.\n\nThis year, there are an estimated 4,696 delegates: 3,949 pledged and 747 automatic (superdelegates). Pledged delegates are committed to support the candidate chosen by state voters. Automatic delegates are the party's major leaders, like former presidents, V-Ps, governors, Congress members and party officials. They are not pledged to any candidate and can't vote on the first ballot at the convention.\n\nSince Biden was himself a presumptive nominee with the party convention slated for August 19-22, it was not illegal for the party to switch from him to Harris as his name was not on the first ballot.\n\nHarris already has the support of 3,359 delegates so far, much more than 1,976 needed to win on a first ballot, according to an Associated Press survey, which is an unofficial tally as Democratic delegates are free to vote for the candidate of their choice when the party picks its new nominee.\n\nHowever, Harris's case is similar to that of Humphrey and against rules and conventions. It lacks legitimacy as she was handed Biden's delegates on a platter without contesting a primary or caucus -- the will of voters, who chose him, not her.\n\nThough Biden's delegates were not legally bound to him as he was the presumptive, not official, nominee, surveys show that most Democrats are happy with Harris as the nominee.\n\nOn the other hand, Biden's delegates are also free to choose another candidate. For example, in 1952, Tennessee's Democratic senator Estes Kefauver was the clear favourite to win the nomination after winning the most primaries and delegates. However, party leaders backed Illinois governor Adlai Stevenson, who wasn't even a candidate before the convention.\n\nBiden knew that it takes months, if not a year, to prepare for primaries and caucuses. However, the party was divided over how to select a nominee if Biden dropped out, meaning Harris wasn't their first choice.\n\nPelosi favoured the competitive process in an open primary to select a nominee before Biden pulled out, though she later endorsed Harris. Even Obama and Schumer favoured a \"mini primary\". Obama wanted Arizona senator and former astronaut Mark Kelly \"at the top of the ticket\" at the convention.\n\nIn a video, New York representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said, \"If you think that there is consensus among the people who want Joe Biden to leave, that they will support vice-president Harris, you would be mistaken.\" Though she also endorsed Harris later.\n\nSeveral other Democrats also favoured an open nominating process at the DNC. California representative Zoe Lofgren favoured a \"mini-primary\", including Harris. \"I don't think we can do a coronation [of Harris],\" she said.\n\nMontana senator Jon Tester and Vermont senator Peter Welch also favoured an open nominating process.\n\nBiden knew that scenario was unlikely in the DNC as Democrats want to present a united face to voters and the Republican Party, which has coalesced around Trump. Dems don't want the DNC to turn into chaos and bitterness.\n\nStill fearing an open contest, Biden knew Harris was his best bet. If she wins, she would be the first woman, African-American and person of South Asian descent to become president and Biden would get some credit. Besides, Harris, his V-P pick in 2020, supported him despite the banner of revolt unfurled by top Democrats and never portrayed herself as his replacement publicly,\n\nBiden couldn't allow an open-for-all contest with hard numbers staring at his face. A July draft memo prepared by Washington, D.C.-based BlueLabs Analytics, a leading provider of analytics services and technology, showed that four prominent Democrats outperformed Biden by five points against Trump in the battleground states of Wisconsin, Michigan, Nevada, Arizona, Georgia, North Carolina and Pennsylvania.\n\nMoreover, these four Democrats -- Kelly, Maryland governor Wes Moore, Pennsylvania governor Josh Shapiro and Michigan governor Gretchen Whitmer -- also outperformed Harris.\n\nBlueLabs interviewed 15,000 voters across Nevada, Arizona, Michigan, Wisconsin, Georgia, North Carolina and Pennsylvania between July 5 and 12, around a week after the debate.\n\n\"Alternative Democratic candidates run ahead of President Biden by an average of three points across the battleground states. Nearly, every tested Democrat performs better than the President. This includes vice-president Harris, who runs better than the President (but behind the average alternative),\" the memo read. Harris was \"behind the average [Democratic] alternative\".\n\nYoung voters, Independents and those who haven't voted since, at least, 2020 are most likely to increase support for an alternative Democratic candidate.\n\nAccording to the memo, voters are \"looking for a fresh face\" and \"those more closely tied to the current administration [including Harris] perform relatively worse than other tested candidates\". Almost twice as many voters say delegates should nominate the best candidate over picking the next in line [Harris].\n\nBiden's strategy has worked so far.\n\nExcept for Moore, all the three top Democrats who were leading Biden and Harris in the BlueLabs survey have endorsed Harris.\n\n\"I couldn't be more confident that Vice President @KamalaHarris is the right person to defeat Donald Trump and lead our country into the future. She has my support for the nomination,\" he tweeted.\n\nWhitmer tweeted: \"Today, not only am I fired up to endorse @KamalaHarris for President of the United States, I'm proud to serve as a co-chair of her campaign. ... Vice President Harris, you have my full support. Let's win this.\"\n\nShapiro tweeted: \"I will do everything I can to help elect @KamalaHarris as the 47th President of the United States.\"\n\nFinally, Obama also endorsed Harris after not mentioning her in tribute to Biden after he quit the race. The former president hinted that the party \"will be navigating uncharted waters in the days ahead\" and called for \"a process from which an outstanding nominee emerges\", clearly hinting that he didn't support Harris.\n\nHowever, the Obamas endorsed Harris on July 26. \"We agree with President Biden that choosing Kamala was one of the best decisions he's made. She has the resume to prove it. There is no doubt in our mind that Kamala Harris has exactly what it takes to win this election and deliver for the American people,\" they said in a statement.\n\nA video showing Harris taking a phone call from the Obamas pledging their support accompanied the statement.\n\nIrrespective of whether Harris beats Trump, Biden had his revenge with the party having no option but to select Harris as the nominee.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": "person",
